instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.57
PP3V42 is 3.4V
ALL SYS PWRGD is 0V
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> all pins 0 Volts
PP5V S4RS3 PULSING
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> IS 3.3V 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> IS 5V

BOARD HAS BEEN WORKED UPON PREVIOUSLY.
A FEW COMPONENTS MISSING WHICH WERE RESTORED. (<CAPACITOR>C1260</CAPACITOR>/1/2)

SMC ALSO REFLOWN/CHANGED

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> all pins 0 Volts"
Pin 8 MUST have voltage; is directly connected to <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Rebuild broken trace...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message: Sorry i meant all pins except Pin 8. getting 3v42

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
"PP5V S4RS3 PULSING"
Any big coil pulsing at same rithm?
Check in SMC bypass; this should provide higher pulse.

Do you get 1-2 pulses, or continuously every 5s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
PP5V S4RS3 - It pulses continuously every 2-3 seconds.

Other Big Coils ( CHECKED WITH RAW BOARD ON TABLE)
L7560 3.3V STABLE
L7430 PULSES BETWEEN 0V TO 0.8V EVERY 2-3 SECONDS
L7630 PULSES BETWEEN 0V TO 0.7V EVERY 2-3 SCONDS
L7320 PULSES BETWEEN 0V TO 1V EVERY 2-3 SECONDS
L7310 PULSES BETWEEN 0V TO 1.1V EVERY 2-3 SCONDS
L7130 STABLE 8.57 VOLTS
L3095 0V

IN SMC BYPASS - PP5V S4RS3 IS SAME. PULSING FROM 0V TO 3.9V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
So you get pulse on CPU core too.
Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>; also <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

Please, use capital letters when really need only...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
Yes Pin 7 and 3 are pulsing

Pin 7 to 2.2V and Zero
Pin 3 to 1.5V

PLT RESET L is stable at 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing from 0.5V to 0V.
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> pulsing from 0.6V to 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board Repair
threads.message:
Possibly CPU issue.

Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Inspect J6100 for corrosion.
Heat CPU with quality flux; in case of accumulated crap underneath.
